Issues.Title: Dynamic base href for routes
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
*@angular/router*
This feature request is for @angular/router


### Description
The route engine uses the *base tag* as the base of its URLs, but there is no programmatic way through the router APIs 
to dynamically change the *base tag*, or the reference used to perform the routing.

Example of used:
In a Micro Frontends application, where we have a container app, and various parts of the application split into small
app built using angular elements, an app that runs inside the app container if you have lazy loading routes,
failed to load parts of the route because they used the *base href* defined in the app container, so the request returns the
HTTP 404 error.


### Describe the solution you'd like
I suggest that it is possible through the Routing API to pass *base-href* to be used in the specific route.

Exemplo:
```
 RouterModule.forRoot(
      [
        {
          path: '',
          pathMatch: 'full',
          redirectTo: 'feature1'
        },
        {
          path: 'feature1',
          loadChildren: () => import('./path/feature1/feature1.module').then(m => m.Feature1Module),
        },
        {
          path: 'feature2',
          loadChildren: () => import('./path/feature2/feature2.module').then(m => m.Feature2Module),
          baseHref:'/app-path/'
        }
      ]
    )
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Through the routing events change the href base tag to the desired path and when the routing is finished returns the tag to the
previous value.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue " Dynamic base href for routes" (#32824)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ensure TestBed restores fields to the most original value
Issues.Body: If `TestBed.applyProviderOverrides` is called multiple times in a single test (happens if someone calls `compileModuleAsync` or `compileModuleSync`), the original fields for `ngComponentDef` are not restored correctly. Subsequent tests will get old versions of overridden providers in these cases.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): ensure TestBed restores fields to the most original value" (#32823)

Issues.Title: PWA App showing white screen due to very slow load on cold start
Issues.Body:
Hi, this is a very complex issue to describe, so I try my best to explain it in full details: We have an PWA app written in Angular, using Angular Service Worker package for PWA functionality. Recently we have noticed via Google Analytics that our page loads has gone too high and users complaining about our PWA app not loading (or very slow loading) in their desktop systems.

So, we investigated this issue and could reproduce it under certain conditions; We found out that it's not something related to our code, because many similar projects with the same library (Angular+ServiceWorker) also have this problem and it does not really matter which version of Angular packages you use, I tried 6, 7, 8 and also 9, but with the same result. Here are some url with Angular PWA demos on it which have the same issue:

https://firestarter-96e46.firebaseapp.com
https://angular-pwa-38ba5.firebaseapp.com
https://pwa.ng

So, these are steps to reproduce this issue on Chrome 76 & 77 (These two versions are the ones I could reproduce on them, Chrome 70 seems to work just fine and I guess this issue started in Chrome 75 or 76):

1. Go to the given URL (Desktop only, not mobile).
2. Click Install button on address bar for installing the PWA app.
3. Close all chrome windows and processes (**Important**)
4. Run PWA app by clicking it's icon on the desktop
5. Window pops up, but with no content, just a white screen.

This is very confusing, Because if you have any chrome window opened before opening the app, it works just fine. That's what makes step 3 so important in reproducing the issue and for having a so-called cold start effect on app start-up.

I tried other PWA apps that were written using Google WorkBox library, and they didn't had this issue. I guess this is somehow related to Angular ServiceWorker implementation causing some conflict with Chrome recent versions. I'm sure this is not something related to our code or even Angular, because it used to work just fine with older chrome versions. I Also submitted this issue on chromium issue tracker, but decided to also submit it in here to see if anyone else has this problem?

Possible Workaround:
After a lot of trial & errors, I noticed that if I put an async script tag in the end of head tag in my index.html, page renders fine, although page loading is still in progress for about 4-5 minutes without any specific reason and then window.load fires.

This is a very frustrating issue and we're losing our customers because of it. I hope and really appreciate if someone could shed some lights on it?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PWA App showing white screen due to very slow load on cold start" (#32800)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): process nested animation metadata
Issues.Body:
In View Engine, animation metadata could occur in nested arrays which
would be flattened in the compiler. When compiling a component for Ivy
however, the compiler no longer statically evaluates a component's
animation metadata and is therefore unable to flatten it statically.
This resulted in an issue to find animations at runtime, as the metadata
was incorrectly registered with the animation engine.

Although it would be possible to statically evaluate the animation
metadata in ngtsc, doing so would prevent reusable animations exported
from libraries from being usable as ngtsc's partial evaluator is unable
to read values inside libraries. This is unlike ngc's usage of static
symbols represented in a library's `.metadata.json`, which explains how
the View Engine compiler is able to flatten the animation metadata
statically.

As an alternative solution, the metadata flattening is now done in the
runtime during the registration of the animation metadata with the
animation engine.

Fixes #32794
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): process nested animation metadata" (#32818)

Issues.Title: Document how to bypass asset processing for CSS preprocessors
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description
With CLI we're able to configure a certain preprocessor to be used when processing styles. And within those styles we might make use of file relative paths as `background: url("../../foo.png")` or `background: url("./bar.png")`.

And as long as the asset is found at its given path at build time - we're fine, right? But let's say it's only guaranteed to be in place at runtime - then we'll end up with a compilation error. And after a few tries of trying to "shake" that file relative path to life you'll most likely end up browsing the Angular official docs for potential solutions.

Obviously using absolute paths is your friend, that's not the point. The point is that there actually is a way of pulling the previous paragraph off. Although, unfortunately, it's not documented. That is, if we're not treating the source code as pure documentation :)

So basically the caret sign (`^`) comes to the rescue and makes `background: url("^../../foo.png")` compile just perfectly fine. And the key to why this works lies within a few lines of code here https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/plugins/postcss-cli-resources.ts#L72. Effectively bypassing the processing (or existence validation if you will) of the asset.

So in short terms I think it would be valuable for CLI consumers to have this (tiny) information in the official docs. It will spare some lucky individuals a few hours of detective work :)

Thanks!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Document how to bypass asset processing for CSS preprocessors" (#32811)

Issues.Title: Promise.prototype.then called on incompatible receiver in Chrome 77.0.3865.90
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package zone.js Maybe. ### Is this a regression? Actually angular is not broken, but a browser update broke the frameworks behavior. It's still working in all other browsers except Chrome 77.0.3865.90 ### Description In Chrome 77.0.3865.90 in some case the following error is thrown for Promises around ReadableStream, WritableStream or TransformStream, but I couldn't come up with a simple reproduction. It was working fine until the most recent Chrome patch. ``` TypeError: Method Promise.prototype.then called on incompatible receiver [object Object] at ZoneAwarePromise.then () ``` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/zaenk/chrome77-zonejs-promise-bug Prereq: node 10 or 12, npm 3.11+, ng cli 8.3.5 * Clone the repo * npm install * ng serve * Open localhost:4200 in an updated Chrome Stable channel (77.0.3865.90) * F12 for console, observe the error message * If it not breaks for the first time, give the dev server and the browser some restart ## üî• Exception or Error 

TypeError: Method Promise.prototype.then called on incompatible receiver [object Object]
    at ZoneAwarePromise.then ()
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.803.5
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.803.5
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.803.5
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.803.5
@angular-devkit/core              8.3.5
@angular-devkit/schematics        8.3.5
@angular/cli                      8.3.5
@ngtools/webpack                  8.3.5
@schematics/angular               8.3.5
@schematics/update                0.803.5
rxjs                              6.4.0
typescript                        3.5.3
webpack                           4.39.2
**Anything else relevant?** ### Browser version Code that throwing this error is working in: * Chrome 76 * Chrome 78 (Beta) * Chrome 79 (Canary) * Firefox 68 * Firefox 69 * Edge 18 * Edge 78 (Dev) * Also might have worked in 77.0.3865.75, but I cannot tell this for sure ### Other * webpack package was not installed at top level node_modules with npm 6.8.x, installing 6.11.3 of npm fixed that Edit: * Here's a fiddle with the working code without angular https://jsfiddle.net/by15stqh/4/ * I tried to debug this for hours, every place where this library uses `await` it returns a Promise, which always have the `then` override from zone. Every object being wrapped is a Promise https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/2e84f4e0cda5ee4d1c9dae0c5789c7225d7c94e5/packages/zone.js/lib/common/promise.ts#L474-L478 * Tried NgZone `runOutsideAngular` but the global promise is still modified by zone, so the result is the same * Tried with zone.js 0.9.1 and 0.10.2, no difference
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Promise.prototype.then called on incompatible receiver in Chrome 77.0.3865.90" (#32802)

Issues.Title: Use Node.js async hooks to support Zone.js
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package

Zone.js

### Description

Zone.js is incompatible with ES2017. Seeing as it is already 2019....it seems time to address this.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Node.js offers the async-hooks API which could support this on that platform.

@JiaLiPassion worked on this a couple years ago in the old repo. https://github.com/angular/zone.js/pull/795

As far as I know, there's no fundamental blocker.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Don't use ES2017.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Use Node.js async hooks to support Zone.js" (#32796)

Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ X ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Issues.Title: Regression: raw-loader is missing
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
Yes, the regression was introduced with #10567


### Description

It is no longer possible to do `require('./my-template.html')` in an AngularJS file. This is, because `raw-loader` was removed with #10567 or, respectively, https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/commit/dfb08b95b73f3e75d0f2cd0c61f336dc86d0769a#diff-fdb0776b9f2db468444818966705634c


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
- This issue is rather obvious and imho doesn't need to be reproduced, just look at the change in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/commit/dfb08b95b73f3e75d0f2cd0c61f336dc86d0769a#diff-fdb0776b9f2db468444818966705634cL310 ... the raw-loader has been removed for `.html` files. 

The suggested alternative of using `directTemplateLoading` doesn't work ... I'm not sure why but my guess is that `directTemplateLoading` is supposed to work only for Angular related stuff. Any js files unrelated to Angular (like e.g. AngularJS files) seem to be loaded in a different way.

The workaround to add `raw-loader!` in front of every `.html`-require is extremely unpleasant.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Regression: raw-loader is missing" (#15653)

Issues.Title: "ng serve" shows compilation successful but browser does not show angular app
Issues.Body:
I am using AWS EC2 ubuntu server, have installed a fresh angular app, run the `ng serve` command on putty from my Windows 7 PC.
**Result on CLI (in putty):** Compilation is successful.
**Problem:** URL is not accessible via browser whether I type it manually with ip and port 8080 as I used in my app or use `-o` with my command. Even if I add `--host 0.0.0.0` or `port` with my `ng serve` command. Neither approach worked out.

**Approaches tried:** 
- Added `--host 0.0.0.0` with `ng serve` command.
- I've checked firewall settings to enable access to node and putty.
- Updated host to "0.0.0.0" in my package.json file.

Please suggest what error there could be? If you have any question further or need any clarification or screenshot, I may also clarify/attach as per request/requirement.

Kindly respond with your solutions/suggestions..

**Edit (Sept 20, 2019, 22:44): **
I've checked out the following threads but neither have any solution devised. 
[https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/7119](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/7119)
[https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/6779](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/6779)

@alan-agius4 @filipesilva @mgechev @filipemelo  any thoughts from your side?

Issues.Title: Server build in Angular 9 isn't generating an ngfactory
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc - [x] server ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8 ### Description When upgrading an Angular 8 workspace that uses server-side rendering, it looks like `@angular-devkit/build-angular:server` isn't generating an `NgModuleFactory`. Previously running that builder would generate something like `AppServerModuleNgFactory`, but when upgrading to Angular 9 it looks like it generates an `AppServerModule` that isn't compatible with `renderModuleFactory` or `ngExpressEngine`. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Clone this repo (based on the angular-io universal example): https://github.com/ca136/no-ngfactory-angular9 Run a build: ``` npm run build:ssr ``` Run the server: ``` npm run serve:ssr ``` ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: deployUrl only changes index.html
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? No ### Description Set `angular.json => projects.name.architect.build.options.deployUrl = "/build/"`. My expectation is 1) all entries of .js/.css files build are changed to /build/ prefix. 2) all built .js/.css files are moved into %build_root%/build/ folder. The point 1) is true; the point 2) however, is false, all scripts are left in %build_root% folder. Basically, this breaks the app since it will try to load scripts from void. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Just set deployUrl to something meaningful in angular.json. Then build the project `ng build --prod` and check the result ‚Äì¬†paths in index.html are changed, but files are left in the build root. ## üî• Exception or Error 

No errors thrown.

Issues.Title: Angular 8 prod build with aot asks sudo password
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [x] build
```
### Description

In linux server when we were doing build without aot (setting aot, buildOtpimizer to false) build was generating fine. 
After we set aot & buildOptimizer & generate build it asks for sudo password after compilation & it stays only for several seconds. If we fail to enter pwd in this time it exits.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

It happened on linux server. I am not sure why build process is changing files permission after creating it.

```
"scripts": {
    "ng": "ng",
    "start": "ng serve",
    "build": "ng build",
    "gzipper": "gzipper",
    "build:prod": "node --max_old_space_size=2048 node_modules/@angular/cli/bin/ng build --prod && gzipper ./dist",
    "test": "ng test",
    "lint": "ng lint",
    "e2e": "ng e2e"
  }
```
User is using `npm run build:prod` to generate build.

## üî• Error

Below is screenshot when process exit before we could enter password.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25152577/65320305-30794080-dbbf-11e9-85fa-1ba832a7633a.png)

And this is when i was able to password and enter

![image (1)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25152577/65320374-5272c300-dbbf-11e9-8272-676cafd1c007.png)

## üåç Your Environment
```
 "devDependencies": {
    "@angular-devkit/build-angular": "~0.803.2",
    "@angular/cli": "~8.3.2",
    "@angular/compiler-cli": "~8.2.4",
    "@angular/language-service": "~8.2.4"
}
```
This is compiler & build versions used in project.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular 8 prod build with aot asks sudo password" (#15641)

Issues.Title: build: examples not working in dev app
Issues.Body:
Fixes a couple of issues related to examples in the dev app:
1. The path mappings for all the new example entry points (e.g. `@angular/material-examples/material/button`) weren't being configured in the System config which meant that any page that consumes any of the examples would break. These changes make it so that whenever we configure a new entry point we automatically configure its examples.
2. The `popover-edit` examples were placed under the stable `cdk` and `material` example packages which is incorrect, because `popover-edit` itself is still experimental. These changes add new `cdk-experimental` and `material-experimental` packages under `material-examples` for consistency with the rest of the repo and so that we don't end up accidentally publishing these examples.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: examples not working in dev app" (#17166)

Issues.Title: build: remove ng_package entry-point workaround
Issues.Body:
We recently had to switch all `ts_library` entry
points to use `ng_module` because the `ng_package`
rule did not properly handle `ts_library` targets
as entry-points.

https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/217db9b216970a400c96a57e2dcd640cc16a8721 fixed this issue upstream and we can
now use `ts_library` instead of `ng_module` for vanilla TS entry-points.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: remove ng_package entry-point workaround" (#17171)

Issues.Title: MatButton.focus ignores origin argument
Issues.Body:
`MatButton` implements `FocusableOption` which implements `focus(origin?: FocusOrigin)`. However, it actually implements just `focus(unused, extraArgumentsHere)`.

#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-qrhvfh

Steps to reproduce:
1. Get reference to `MatButton`
2. Call `MatButton.focus(origin)` where `origin = 'keyboard'|'mouse'|whatever`
 
 
#### Expected Behavior
Focus should be via `'origin'`, and class `cdk-origin-focused` should be applied

#### Actual Behavior
Focus is always done via `'program'` and `cdk-program-focused` is applied

#### Workaround

Focus can be done via FocusMonitor instead.

#### Environment

- Angular: 7.0.0
- CDK/Material: 8.1.4
- Browser(s): Version 77.0.3865.75 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Debian Rodette
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatButton.focus ignores origin argument" (#17174)

Issues.Title: refactor: clean up deprecated uses of combineLatest
Issues.Body: The signature of `combineLatest` that uses individual parameters has been deprecated. These changes switch to the new recommended way which passes in the observables as an array.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor: clean up deprecated uses of combineLatest" (#17168)

Issues.Title: fix(a11y): focus monitor not identifying touch focus inside shadow root
Issues.Body:
`FocusMonitor` uses a `touchstart` listener on the `document` to identify when an element was focused via touch. The problem is that if an element is inside the shadow DOM, the `event.target` will be set to the shadow root. These changes use `composedPath` to get the event target which accounts for the shadow DOM.

**Note:** I was unable to write a test that captures the error, because our fake touch events weren't behaving similarly to the ones the browser dispatches from the shadow DOM.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(a11y): focus monitor not identifying touch focus inside shadow root" (#17167)

Issues.Title: fix(drag-drop): unable to drop into connected sibling after scrolling into view via the parent
Issues.Body:
In #16681 we added some logic that updates the cached dimensions if the document is scrolled while dragging, however it didn't account for any scrollable parent nodes that might've been scrolled. These changes switch the event listener to use capturing so that we can pick up all of the elements being scrolled.

**Note:** this was tricky to reproduce in a test, but I've added more context in a comment with a reference to the issue that it fixes.

Fixes #17144.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(drag-drop): unable to drop into connected sibling after scrolling into view via the parent" (#17162)

Issues.Title: build: fix bazel devserver not launching
Issues.Body:
The custom devserver implementation does currently not
work due to a breaking change in the `rules_nodejs` repo.

Apparently a `nodejs_binary` no longer generates an executable
output without either `.bat` or `.sh`. This is something we
relied on in the devserver launcher script. The fix is as simple
as resolving the executable with `.sh` extension as we run the
devserver launcher from within a `sh_binary` already.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: fix bazel devserver not launching" (#17160)
